name: GetStripePaymentLinks
description:
Retrieve a list of Stripe payment links.

This tool calls the Stripe API to fetch a list of all your payment links. It should be used when you need to access or display your payment links managed through Stripe.

parameters.name: pagination_ending_before
parameters.description: An object ID cursor to define the starting point in the list for pagination, retrieving the previous page.

value_schema.description: A cursor for use in pagination. `ending_before` is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, starting with `obj_bar`, your subsequent call can include `ending_before=obj_bar` in order to fetch the previous page of the list.

parameters.name: fields_to_expand
parameters.description: List of fields in the response that should be expanded. Use field names as strings.

value_schema.description: Specifies which fields in the response should be expanded.

parameters.name: object_return_limit
parameters.description: Specifies the maximum number of payment link objects to retrieve, ranging from 1 to 100. Default is 10.

value_schema.description: A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between 1 and 100, and the default is 10.

parameters.name: pagination_starting_after_cursor
parameters.description: The object ID to define your place in the list for pagination. Use it to fetch the next page of payment links.

value_schema.description: A cursor for use in pagination. `starting_after` is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, ending with `obj_foo`, your subsequent call can include `starting_after=obj_foo` in order to fetch the next page of the list.

parameters.name: include_active_payment_links
parameters.description: Return active payment links only. Set to `false` to list inactive payment links.

value_schema.description: Only return payment links that are active or inactive (e.g., pass `false` to list all inactive payment links).

metadata.description: Tools that enable LLMs to interact directly with the Stripe API.

parameters.name: active
parameters.description: Only return payment links that are active or inactive (e.g., pass `false` to list all inactive payment links).

value_schema.description: Only return payment links that are active or inactive (e.g., pass `false` to list all inactive payment links).

parameters.name: ending_before
parameters.description: A cursor for use in pagination. `ending_before` is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, starting with `obj_bar`, your subsequent call can include `ending_before=obj_bar` in order to fetch the previous page of the list.

value_schema.description: A cursor for use in pagination. `ending_before` is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, starting with `obj_bar`, your subsequent call can include `ending_before=obj_bar` in order to fetch the previous page of the list.

parameters.name: expand
parameters.description: Specifies which fields in the response should be expanded.

value_schema.description: Specifies which fields in the response should be expanded.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between 1 and 100, and the default is 10.

value_schema.description: A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between 1 and 100, and the default is 10.

parameters.name: starting_after
parameters.description: A cursor for use in pagination. `starting_after` is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, ending with `obj_foo`, your subsequent call can include `starting_after=obj_foo` in order to fetch the next page of the list.

value_schema.description: A cursor for use in pagination. `starting_after` is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, ending with `obj_foo`, your subsequent call can include `starting_after=obj_foo` in order to fetch the next page of the list.
